awd_titl_txt: Expanding the Pipeline: Immersive Learning Curriculum Development for High School Cybersecurity Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Purdue University Northwest is developing an innovative cybersecurity curriculum to provide high school students with hands-on activities in an immersive learning environment. The following activities will be developed for cybersecurity teaching in high school environments: virtual reality three-dimension games, robotic programming games, practical ethical hacking labs, and cyber forensics labs based on simulated cases. This project is expected to provide an immersive, learning-based curriculum for high school cybersecurity education. One of the goals is to minimize preparation efforts, and requirements of cybersecurity skills and content knowledge from teachers looking to incorporate cybersecurity into their classroom education. This will address the lack of cybersecurity educators and will make cybersecurity education more accessible to students in rural areas. Through the proposed outcomes, more students will be exposed to cybersecurity education during high school and are likely to be more motivated to pursue higher education and careers in this field, which will ultimately strengthen future cybersecurity workforce development.

Virtual reality three-dimension games will be developed to simulate system vulnerabilities, attacks, security protection techniques and social engineering scams. Robotic programming games will be developed for robots, such as Sparki and Raspberry Pi, to simulate robotic functionality and security attack scenarios that take advantage of programming security vulnerabilities. Cyber forensics investigation cases and cybersecurity attack labs will be developed based on a virtual network system that simulate a classic enterprise system with business functioning and security components. The virtual reality three dimension games, robotic programming games, cyber forensics cases, and cybersecurity attack labs are expected to be integrated with other instructional methods to promote student education through interactive practices. The cybersecurity curriculum and instructor companion materials developed through this project will be shared and disseminated to the cybersecurity education community via sharing with GenCyber student and teacher summer camps, and in K12 teacher conferences and organizations.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the NSF SFS Capacity building project (1723666, 2017-2022) include

  1. A study of the cybersecurity course offered at high schools via online search was accomplished in 2018. The result showed that for a total of 173 districts reviewed in 23 states (at least 5 districts per state), 15 districts offered a cybersecurity course and 12 of them are located in metropolitan areas. 
  2. A K12 cybersecurity education topic identification was conducted through an online survey in 2018. The survey was distributed to K12 educators through GenCyber summer teacher camps, the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) annual conference, the International Society of Technology in Education (ISTE) Commons online forums, and the ECS Open Group at CSForAllTeachers.org.  A total of 214 responses were received. All responses showed interest or high interest in teaching cybersecurity, 97% of the responses agreed to learn more about cybersecurity, 73% of the responses agreed that cybersecurity games could promote cybersecurity education interest, 98% of the responses agreed that students could learn cybersecurity through gameplay, and 85% of the responses agreed that they would use the games to teach cybersecurity. The results also showed that many teachers did not have the basic computer setup and management skills.
  3. A total of 69 cybersecurity education curriculum modules were developed for high school classroom teaching and extracurricular activities. These modules included 16 virtual reality 3-D games, 9 robotic programming games, 42 cybersecurity and forensics labs, together with short lecture slides and assessment quizzes, and 8 modules were updated to reflect the technology advancement and relevance. Most of the modules are available online at https://games.pnwcyber.com. A total of 24 of these modules were integrated into an introductory cybersecurity course (ITS19900) for non-IT college students.
  4. A course module effectiveness assessment has been conducted through feedback connected from summer camp attendees. K12 teachers responded favorably to the games agreeing significantly that they were clear with directions, helpful in teaching students about cybersecurity, and interesting and fun to complete.  All teachers agreed that the games functioned properly. Students' assessment showed that the directions for the games were clear, and the games were interesting and fun to complete. Findings from high school students' summer camps showed that most students learned cybersecurity better through games (70-93%) and found that the games were appropriate for their age (73-86%). Also, students’ knowledge was gained, and interests in cybersecurity also grew, with ethical hacking and digital forensics making the biggest gains in interest levels following the camp.
  5. Course modules have been disseminated to the K12 community through various mechanisms and outreach/engagement activities. Course modules have been exposed to 1) 287 high schools students via 9 NSA/NSF funded GenCyber student summer camps (with about 50% of the participants being underrepresented minorities and 25% of the participants being female students); 2) 45 high school teachers/educators through 2 summer camps supported by NSA/NSF GenCyber Program, one teacher summer camp and one free course offering supported by this project; 3) 6 non-IT college students through a pilot cybersecurity course (ITS19900) offering; 4) over 1,000 high school students via presentation/hands-on demonstration at numerous STEM outreach and engagement events; 5) cybersecurity education community via six (6) conference and journal publications and presentations with over 180 citations.

Last Modified: 11/04/2022
Modified by: Michael Tu
por.por_txt_cntn:
The outcomes of the NSF SFS Capacity building project (1723666, 2017-2022) include

A study of the cybersecurity course offered at high schools via online search was accomplished in 2018. The result showed that for a total of 173 districts reviewed in 23 states (at least 5 districts per state), 15 districts offered a cybersecurity course and 12 of them are located in metropolitan areas.  
A K12 cybersecurity education topic identification was conducted through an online survey in 2018. The survey was distributed to K12 educators through GenCyber summer teacher camps, the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) annual conference, the International Society of Technology in Education (ISTE) Commons online forums, and the ECS Open Group at CSForAllTeachers.org.  A total of 214 responses were received. All responses showed interest or high interest in teaching cybersecurity, 97% of the responses agreed to learn more about cybersecurity, 73% of the responses agreed that cybersecurity games could promote cybersecurity education interest, 98% of the responses agreed that students could learn cybersecurity through gameplay, and 85% of the responses agreed that they would use the games to teach cybersecurity. The results also showed that many teachers did not have the basic computer setup and management skills.
A total of 69 cybersecurity education curriculum modules were developed for high school classroom teaching and extracurricular activities. These modules included 16 virtual reality 3-D games, 9 robotic programming games, 42 cybersecurity and forensics labs, together with short lecture slides and assessment quizzes, and 8 modules were updated to reflect the technology advancement and relevance. Most of the modules are available online at https://games.pnwcyber.com. A total of 24 of these modules were integrated into an introductory cybersecurity course (ITS19900) for non-IT college students. 
A course module effectiveness assessment has been conducted through feedback connected from summer camp attendees. K12 teachers responded favorably to the games agreeing significantly that they were clear with directions, helpful in teaching students about cybersecurity, and interesting and fun to complete.  All teachers agreed that the games functioned properly. Students' assessment showed that the directions for the games were clear, and the games were interesting and fun to complete. Findings from high school students' summer camps showed that most students learned cybersecurity better through games (70-93%) and found that the games were appropriate for their age (73-86%). Also, students’ knowledge was gained, and interests in cybersecurity also grew, with ethical hacking and digital forensics making the biggest gains in interest levels following the camp.
Course modules have been disseminated to the K12 community through various mechanisms and outreach/engagement activities. Course modules have been exposed to 1) 287 high schools students via 9 NSA/NSF funded GenCyber student summer camps (with about 50% of the participants being underrepresented minorities and 25% of the participants being female students); 2) 45 high school teachers/educators through 2 summer camps supported by NSA/NSF GenCyber Program, one teacher summer camp and one free course offering supported by this project; 3) 6 non-IT college students through a pilot cybersecurity course (ITS19900) offering; 4) over 1,000 high school students via presentation/hands-on demonstration at numerous STEM outreach and engagement events; 5) cybersecurity education community via six (6) conference and journal publications and presentations with over 180 citations.
